body: @gianm The "dimHasValues" check is responsible for avoiding writing a column if there was no data at all for a dimension across indexes
@navis there's some merge conflicts now, hopefully they are small
Success.
@fjy in that case we should mark roaring as unsafe to use in 0.8.x?
I think 0.8.3-rc4 is appropriate, as roaring is not an experimental feature so bug fixes are important.
0.8.4 would be cool too.
@gianm resolved conflicts.
:+1: after travis
Success
Success... I can't tell if that is bad or good.
I've reviewed IndexMerger and IndexIO as per request and I think it is cool :+1: on the changes there
:+1: I think this looks cool and it is crazy we missed this optimization :P
:+1: looks good to me
Closing, for now.
Success

I thought that CascadeExtractionFn is essential to support chaining in current ExtractionFn interface but it is inconvenient to use.
So, I added CascadeDimensionSpec that uses CascadeExtractionFn for only internal use and external input from users is jut array of ExtractionFn s.
However, it receives both CascadeExtractonFn(even though it is only for internal use) and array of ExtractionFn s because of serde, which makes that the patch looks unclear.
@b-slim, ok, i will explain it later when i finish some other things.
@xvrl As you said it's broken, sorry. I've reverted the logic. Thanks.
success

I understand what you are saying @jon-wei, @drcrallen .
So I'm gonna update the patch that CascadeExtractionFn can have array argument and handle chaining with inner functions.
Then, I can remove CasecadeExtractionDimension.

Success.

Success

reopening as #2213 doesn't have a fix but hopes to provide more information when it fails.

setting for historical

```
druid.processing.buffer.sizeBytes=1000000000
```

Is this error related to this setting?
@fjy fixed test fail
are you getting the error at query time or ingestion time? if it failed at query time, did you specify "size" attribute same as that at ingestion time in thetaSketch aggregators and post aggregators?
also try keeping druid.processing.buffer.sizeBytes a power of 2 for potentially better performance due to alignments.

ingestion size= query size = 4194304
this error happens in query time.  the exception is from "historical" log
can you paste your indexing json and query json file?
my guess is that, at query time, you are not specifying size=4194304 in your sketch post aggregators..

aside from some minor comments, this PR looks good to me. However, I would agree with @gianm about not completely replacing IndexMerger with this but release them together and give user ability to choose. After a while, when it has been used in production in multiple clusters, we can remove IndexMerger.
One quick way of doing that would be to make IndexMergerV9 extend IndexMerger with all the relevant methods overridden, then based on a runtime.properties configuration bind either IndexMerger or IndexMergerV9 instance in guice.

Side-note: I hadn't really looked at IndexMaker code much and curious to know at high level what high level improvements make this better than IndexMaker? can anyone with relevant knowledge pls answer.

you would need to specify "size=4194304" attribute for thetaSketchSetOp post aggregator as well.

I missed it in the documentation, will update that.
yeah, it works now! 3ks~
Maybe we should also improve error message?
will see to error message but that is kind of harder in this case.

@navis Can you squash your commits?
@himanshug IndexMaker iterates through every row each time it tries to build a column. This is a much more efficient implementation.
@navis I'm guessing this is the PR to review right?
I'm also wondering why the hashCode() function for SegmentAnalysis changed, but :+1: otherwise
At a high level I think this PR is pretty good. A few comments overall.
@himanshug Another reason is IndexMaker keep all needed values in memory when it tries to build a column, it will cause memory pressure and hurt performance.

We are supporting GET operation on these APIs
1. /druid/coordinator/v1/datasources/{dataSourceName}/intervals/{interval} 
2. /druid/coordinator/v1/datasources/{dataSourceName}/intervals/{interval}?simple 
3. /druid/coordinator/v1/datasources/{dataSourceName}/intervals/{interval}?full

We should also support DELETE operation on these APIs
1. /druid/coordinator/v1/datasources/{dataSourceName} 
2. /druid/coordinator/v1/datasources/{dataSourceName}/intervals/{interval}?kill=true 

This will ensure single way to represent intervals. 

As of now, we support Delete Operation with interval as QueryString parameter resulting in inconsistency in handling intervals as compared to corresponding GET APIs where interval is in Path parameter.
/druid/coordinator/v1/datasources/{dataSourceName}?kill=true&**interval={myISO8601Interval}**

Let me know if you agree/disagree on this approach.
@navis any chance of resolving merge conflicts and finishing this one up?

I just realized that the new endpoint isn't documented at http://druid.io/docs/latest/design/coordinator.html.  Should it be?  Or, are there some types of endpoints that are deliberately not documented at druid.io/docs and this is one of them?
@rasahner This should be documented. Can you submit a PR?
@fjy fixed conflict and addressed comments.

@fjy I've talked with @sirpkt and concluded we need both of implementation in druid because this(#2217) has different semantic with current implementation on multi-valued dimensions, but which might be useful in some cases.
@navis okay. Will @sirpkt reopen his PR? Just as an FYI, the JS implementations of features will be much slower than native Java implementations.

As @navis mentioned in #2217 , we decided to keep both patch as each has its own advantage in different cases.
So, I reopen the PR.
@drcrallen @gianm @himanshug what about now?

The reason for lookup to be done early is to improve performance, lookup is generally a costly operation and multiple lookups should generally be avoided whenever possible. I believe this would slow down FilteredAggregator a lot. 
Can you run some performance benchmarks ?

Please excuse me for the silence, I have been busy with some other work to do.

I think I found a valuable Hadoop configuration property called "mapreduce.job.classloader". This is set to false per default. Programmatically setting it to true just helped me in a different project to use some older version of protobuf libraries than the ones used by Hadoop. So setting this property might be worth a quick try.

I will try to look into that.
@fjy @drcrallen can you pls take a look at latest code and review/merge?

@sirpkt i am not sure how delaying the call to the method level will avoid the NPE.
Can we make it in a way where we can avoid looking up stuff multiple times ?

Hi @guobingkun , is there a proposal related to this?

At first glance this seems to be trying to make the cluster have some level of self-awareness. This is a non-trivial thing because there isn't really a solid concept or delineation between "service" and "capacities". 

To me it would make more sense to have a host:port combination announce itself, maybe with some predefined set of capacities, but then have any state information be accessible through endpoints exposed at the host:port, with API guaranteed by what type of capability the service has announced.

I'm specifically cautious about having the Announcer store state.

did a scan, looks like a step in right direction, waiting to see the impl for SegmentAllocator.
i'm not sure about the name kafka-indexing-service which gave me the notion that this was some kind of "indexing service", which rings me overlord bcoz of the renaming history

also, i believe, we should set the "scope" for this PR to at least result in a working (even if experimental) version of no-window period realtime ingestion with tranquility.
Minor questions from my side, ok as is if they are rejected by author :+1:

@himanshug SegmentAllocator has an implementation in KafkaIndexTask.

Do you have a suggestion for a better name for kafka-indexing-service? I just called it that because it has Kafka stuff for the indexing service.

Hmm IMO this PR should be scoped to be the base for tranquility working and for kafka working. It actually doesn't fully achieve either one but it was getting big enough that I thought it made sense to cut it off at this point and do the rest in follow on PRs.

I think the follow on PRs would be:
1. One supporting Kafka that introduces a supervisor that actually spawns a series of KafkaIndexTasks
2. One supporting Tranquility that introduces a push-oriented task based on the FiniteAppenderatorDriver, which Tranquility can push to
3. A Tranquility PR (in the Tranquility repo) that coordinates that new task in (2)
@guobingkun I had put together some suggestions here https://github.com/druid-io/druid/issues/2040 it doesn't look any of those have been taken into account.
